description.narrative:
The Strategic Partnership (SP) "Towards a Worldwide Influencing Network" is a Lobby and Advocacy programme with the Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The programme enables global and local influencing work on three thematic areas: 1) Right to Food; 2) Greater Responsibility in Finance for Development; 3) Conflict and Fragility. The ambition of the SP is to achieve policy changes by governments and the private sector to the benefit of groups facing poverty and injustice, and to strengthen civil society#s capacity todemand for such change. The SP is implemented over a period of 5 years by an Alliance consisting of Oxfam Novib and SOMO.
This project falls under the thematic area Conflict and Fragility. Through our work Oxfam Novib and SOMO aimto achieve that more marginalized groups have a say in policies that affect their lives; governments and international institutions support inclusion of women and promote protection of marginalized groups in security and peace building; and the private sector contributes to peace and development. Within this Theory of Change, this is a regional project which focuses on engaging Civil Society Organisations with the African Union and the Regional Economic Communities (RECs), based on three focus countries-South Sudan, Central African Republic and Niger # as well as Somaliland, to ensure more people-centred Security and Sector Reform (SSR) processes. Oxfam will work together with the African Security Sector Network (ASSN). The project has the following objective: Improved implementation of the African Union (AU) Security Sector Reform (SSR) Policy Framework as a result of interaction with Civil Society Organisations (CSOs). As an intermediate change, RECs will develop sub-regional or make effective SSR Strategies that ensure security sector actors in country are accountable and responsive to the needs of their people. Three approaches will be used to achieve the objective. Firstly, research will map the CSO landscape in target areas and assess their capacity needs. Data collected on the ground level impact of SSR will be used for evidence-based influencing. The AU and RECs will be assessed to provide greater understanding of how the AU and RECs (IGAD, ECOWAS and ECCAS) can support the participation of CSOs and to identify lessons-learned and gaps in the development and implementation of African SSR. Secondly, training will be used to strengthening the capacities of CSOs on SSR, addressing gender; the role of CS in SSR; the role of SSR in peace negotiations and processes; and Security Sector Governance and Management. CSOs will subsequently develop context-based strategies to engage in SSR both at the national and multilateral (AU and RECs) level.
Finally, CSOs will develop and use influencing strategies to engage policy makers on SSR at the AU and relevant RECs, through advocacy and networking.

participating-org.narrative:
The African Security Sector Network (ASSN) was created at Elmina, Ghana, in November 2003 out of a recognition of the need to harmonise and facilitate the activities of the various African organisations working in the area of Security Sector Reform and Governance(SSR/G).
The principal objective of the network is to promote democratically governed and effective security for the peoples of Africa, and to enhance the capacity of African governments, security institutions, legislatures and civil society organizations to undertake and own Security Sector Reform (SSR) programmes and projects.
The ASSN has developed as a multidisciplinary network spanningacademics, think-tanks, CSOs, security practitioners (active and retired), legislators in defence and security committees, etc, with a pan-African character that enables experiences from different traditions of security organisation and practice (Anglophone, Francophone and Lusophone) to be shared.
The network derives its core strength from its diverse competencies and locations (which enable it to work for change from both within and without); from a capacity for internal debate; and an ability to engage a broad range of security actors (national, regional and international), as well as policy-and decision-makers.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to life and security
